Issues.Title: Deno support or Deno rewrite pilot
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request
Would like [Deno](https://deno.land/) runtime support.

### Description
This is a new runtime that has was created by [Ryan Dahl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Dahl), the original creator of [NodeJS](https://nodejs.org/en/). It has several new advantages:

- Use of Promises
- Uses TypeScript out of the box
- no need for node_modules
- uses urls to load dependencies (might be a plus or minus).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Deno support or Deno rewrite pilot" (#31580)

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): index information about owning and imported NgModule
Issues.Body:
Add a information about the owning NgModule of a component and the
NgModule that the owner imports to the indexing API.

Matching selectors to class declarations across Angular compilation
units is currently very difficult, if possible at all. Providing
references to the owning and imported NgModules gives a workaround that
will work in many cases, at least for matching element selectors.
Following is an analysis of how this works on an indexer's side.

The idea is because selectors are unique in NgModules, when a selector
on a component is encountered an indexer implementation may emit the
selector information on the NgModule class declaration, for example
in a form like `$MODULE::selector::$SELECTOR`. When the selector is
later encountered in a template, references to
`$MODULE::selector::$SELECTOR` for each `$MODULE` in the imported
NgModule are optimistically emitted. Hanging references, of course, are
ignored.

This does not resolve issues of reexports and is a naive solution, but
will work for now.

Issues.Title: fix(language-service): Eagarly initialize data members
Issues.Body:
Data members in `TypeScriptServiceHost` should be eagerly
initialized to address `strictPropertyInitialization` in https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/24571. This eliminates the need to
constantly check for truthiness and makes code much more readable.

More PRs to follow to address issue/24571.

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): support types narrowing for template context of NgIf
Issues.Body:
This commits adds the `ngTemplateContextGuard` static method to the `NgIf` directive. The function of this static method is to narrow the template rendering context variable `ctx` within generated type checking code for consumers of the directive. ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [ ] Bugfix - [x] Feature - [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables) - [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes) - [ ] Build related changes - [ ] CI related changes - [ ] Documentation content changes - [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes - [ ] Other... Please describe: ## What is the current behavior? Previously, the ngIf only supported `ngTemplateGuard_ngIf` guard which narrows the expression passed to an @Input of the directive. For more details see https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/30248. It can't narrow types for template reference variable. ## What is the new behavior? The new behaviour is to constrain a `NgIf` template reference variable so that for the following template: ```html
{{ x.unknown }}
``` the compiler will generate the type-check block (TCB): ```typescript if (NgIf.ngTemplateContextGuard(_t1, _t2) && { "foo": "bar" }) { var _t3 = _t2.$implicit; var _t4 = document.createElement("div"); "" + _t3.unknown; } ``` and it will fail to compile with the error `Property 'unknown' does not exist on type '{ "foo": string; }'` ## Does this PR introduce a breaking change? - [x] Yes - [ ] No As part of the changes, the `NgIf` directive and `NgIfContext` class become generic with default type `any`. Before: ``` @Directive({selector: '[ngIf]'}) export class NgIf { private _context: NgIfContext = new NgIfContext(); ... } export class NgIfContext { public $implicit: any = null; public ngIf: any = null; } ``` After: ``` @Directive({selector: '[ngIf]'}) export class NgIf { private _context: NgIfContext = new NgIfContext(null !, null !); ... } export class NgIfContext { constructor(public $implicit: T, public ngIf: T) {} } ``` Since the `any` default type is used I can't predict exactly which impact it will have on end users. ## Other information Fix #31556
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(ivy): support types narrowing for template context of NgIf" (#31568)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): set LOCALE_ID when using the injector
Issues.Body:
In `BrowserModule` the value of `LOCALE_ID` is defined in the `APPLICATION_MODULE_PROVIDERS` after `APP_INITIALIZER` has run.
This PR ensures that `LOCALE_ID` is also set for ivy at the same moment which allows the application to fetch the locale from a backend (for example).

Fixes #31465


I also took the opportunity to define the default locale id as a constant for all packages (not just core/render3).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): set LOCALE_ID when using the injector" (#31566)

Issues.Title: Default Content-type entity header for JSON differs between Angular vs AngularJs
Issues.Body:
**IMPORTANT**
This is not necessarily a bug. Primarily I am just trying to gather some additional information about different behaviour of AngularJs (`$http`) and Angular (`HttpClient`) APIs.

Please note that I've asked the same question on SO and Gitter but haven't received any answers so I decided to ask it there:

In AngularJs the default `Content-type` for `JSON` request is set like:

`Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8`

This is the part of the AngularJs code that does it:

[http.js](https://github.com/angular/angular.js/blob/6706353a71e3c11c56c0b19be03600dac57aafe1/src/ng/http.js#L333)

... and this is the commit in which `charset=UTF-8` parameter was added:

[angular/angular.js@10f80d7](https://github.com/angular/angular.js/commit/10f80d7d2918f98262090b425ecc294d9518aa7e)

Now in the case of Angular only 

`Content-Type: application/json` 

is used:

[xhr_backend.ts](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/f8096d499324cf0961f092944bbaedd05364eea1/packages/http/src/backends/xhr_backend.ts#L165)

Side note:
We've noticed this when migrating from AngularJs (`$http`) to Angular (`HttpClient`).

Does anyone know why this difference?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Default Content-type entity header for JSON differs between Angular vs AngularJs " (#31563)

Issues.Title: NG SERVE is missing modules when recompiling.
Issues.Body:
# üêû NG SERVE is missing modules when recompiling. ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [X] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No, It occurs only in ANGULAR CLI 8 generated app ### Description Generating an application with Angular CLI 8 and using ng serve, when editing any code, modules are lost when recompiling. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ``` $ ng new portal-sib --enable-ivy --style=scss $ ng add @angular/material (import any module - e.g. MatButtonModule - and include html code) $ ng serve (Everything works) (Edit any code and save. After re-compile, mat-button no longer works) ``` I also tried to import material manually but I get the same error. I also tried to work without Angular Material but I can't use ngFor in my own module because it works only on first ng serve and miss CommonModule on re-compile. ## üî• Exception or Error No error is displayed when the problem occurs with the Angular Material. But when I'm using ngFor in my own module, the following error appears: 



ERROR Error: Template error: Can't bind to 'ngForOf' since it isn't a known property of 'li'.
    at createUnknownPropertyError (core.js:15130)
    at elementPropertyInternal (core.js:14996)
    at Module.…µ…µproperty (core.js:16581)
    at CarouselBannersComponent_Template (carousel-banners.component.html:6)
    at executeTemplate (core.js:14545)

Issues.Title: Ivy: enableIvy:true ng start rebuild causes custom directive not to be created
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Unknown ### Description When `"enableIvy": true` and using `npm start` - custom directives are not created if template file where they are used is changed and the project rebuilt. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - Create new app with Ivy enabled and add a directive ``` npx @angular/cli new test01 --enable-ivy --defaults cd test01 npm run ng -- generate directive test-directive ``` - Open the file `test-directive.directive.ts` - Add `console.log('directive constructor');` in the `TestDirectiveDirective` class constructor code just to monitor directive creation and save the file - Open `app.component.html` and place the directive attribute `appTestDirective` at the `

` element (or any other element - does not matter) and save the file - Serve the app ``` npm start ``` - Open http://localhost:4200, open developer tools and refresh the browser - you should see "directive constructor" logged in the browser console - Change anything in the `app.component.html` (you can even change the text of the first line which is an HTML comment) What happens: The application rebuilds and reloads but you no longer see "directive constructor" The only way to bring directive back is to restart the `npm start` The problem happens with both Node 10.9.0 and Node 12.6.0. Similar problem occurs with pipes but after changing something in the `app.component.html` where the pipe is used, app rebuilt and browser refreshed, there is an error in the browser console: ``` main.ts:12 Error: The pipe 'testPipe' could not be found! at getPipeDef$1 (core.js:30810) at Module.…µ…µpipe (core.js:30776) at AppComponent_Template (app.component.html:8) at executeTemplate (core.js:14533) at checkView (core.js:15957) at componentRefresh (core.js:15715) at refreshChildComponents (core.js:14214) at refreshDescendantViews (core.js:14120) at ComponentFactory$1.create (core.js:28413) at ApplicationRef.bootstrap (core.js:35354) ``` The problem disappears as soon as you opt out of Ivy usage by changing `tsconfig.app.json` `angularCompilerOptions` to: ``` "angularCompilerOptions": { "enableIvy": false } ``` ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Type check directive template context
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

@angular/compiler

### Description

Template contexts appear not to be checked.

```
    <ng-container *ngIf="data(); let d">
      {{ d.a }}
      {{ d.c }}
    </ng-container>
```

There is zero checking for the type of `d`.

Example: https://github.com/pauldraper/angular-template-context I would like `ng build` to fail.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Template context types are type checked.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Don't use template contexts.

I've also tried using Ivy but it seems broken.

```
ERROR in __ng_typecheck__.ts:5:22 - error TS2304: Cannot find name 'Partial'.

5 const _ctor1: (init: Partial<Pick<i1.NgIf, "ngIf" | "ngIfThen" | "ngIfElse">>) => i1.NgIf = (null!);
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Type check directive template context" (#31556)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add defer attributes to classic scripts
Issues.Body: This change synchronizes the behavior of classic scripts and module scripts (`type="module"`).  Module scripts are deferred by default.  Also, certain injected scripts are not considered module scripts even in a ES2015+ build due to the strict mode behavior of module scripts.  Deferring such scripts also ensures consistent execution in those scenarios.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add defer attributes to classic scripts" (#15087)

Issues.Title: Include ScopedTree in the public API of @angular-devkit/schematics
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->
While creating schematics for a project on top of the `ng-new` and `ng-add` I needed to execute a sequence of rules scoped to a subfolder in the workspace. I noticed that there is a `ScopedTree` in the schematics package, but it is not exposed in the public API. I used it to create a `scopedToDir` utility:

```
export function scopedToDir(dir: string, rule: Rule): Rule {
    return (tree: Tree, context: SchematicContext) => {
        return callRule(rule, of(new ScopedTree(tree, dir)), context).pipe(
            map(() => tree));
    };
}
```

Which can then be used like this:

```
scopedToDir(dir, chain([
    createSomeFiles(),
    modifySomeFiles(),
    foo()
]))
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
It would be nice if the `ScopedTree` would be exported in the public API as it offers useful functionality.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

Currently, I'm importing like this:
```
import { ScopedTree } from '@angular-devkit/schematics/src/tree/scoped';
```
But I think this is like relying on undocumented functionality, which may change at any time, without warning.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Include ScopedTree in the public API of @angular-devkit/schematics" (#15079)

Issues.Title: angular.json: sourceMap.vendor-option in build has no affect on serve
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Kinda, if I use ng serve --vendorSourceMap, I'm getting the source maps. But this flag is deprecated and it seems like the sourceMap.vendor-option of the angular.json is the new way to go. ### Description According to the [documentation](https://angular.io/guide/workspace-config#project-tool-configuration-options), the serve section in angular.json overrides build defaults and supplies additional serve defaults. This seems not to be happening with the following configuration: ```JSON ... "build": { "sourceMap": { "vendor": true, "scripts": true }, ... } ``` If I'm running `ng serve` the source maps for my library are missing. If I move this option to the serve section, the source maps are getting transferred to client. It seems, like the compiled output is the same for build and serve. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. run `ng new my-app` 2. cd to my-app 3. run `ng g library my-lib` 4. Call MyLibComponent in app.component.html: `` and update app.module.ts with the necessary imports. 5. Set the following option in angular.json ```JSON ... "build": { "sourceMap": { "vendor": true, "scripts": true }, ... } ``` 6. run `ng b my-lib && ng serve` If you now inspect the application within the browsers DevTools you won't find the my-lib.component.ts If you set the sourceMap option under serve, you'll get the *.ts file. ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 8.1.1
Node: 10.15.3
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.1.1
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.801.1
@angular-devkit/build-angular      0.801.1
@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr   0.801.1
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer    0.801.1
@angular-devkit/build-webpack      0.801.1
@angular-devkit/core               8.1.1
@angular-devkit/schematics         8.1.1
@ngtools/json-schema               1.1.0
@ngtools/webpack                   8.1.1
@schematics/angular                8.1.1
@schematics/update                 0.801.1
ng-packagr                         5.3.0
rxjs                               6.4.0
typescript                         3.4.5
webpack                            4.35.2
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "angular.json: sourceMap.vendor-option in build has no affect on serve" (#15064)

Issues.Title: Assets not copied when path contains a space
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [X] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No ### Description When an Angular CLI Project is located under a folder with a space in the name, the assets are missing in the production bundles. A common case is the `Programm Files`-Directory in windows systems. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Create a new Angular application under a folder with a space in the name. 2. Add some assets to the application 3. Execute `ng build --prod` The `assets` folder is missing in the created bundle. ## üî• Exception or Error Unfortunately there is no Exception/Error. ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 8.0.3
Node: 12.4.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.0.2
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router, service-worker

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.800.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.800.3
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.800.3
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.800.3
@angular-devkit/core              8.0.4
@angular-devkit/schematics        8.0.4
@angular/cdk                      8.0.1
@angular/cli                      8.0.3
@angular/flex-layout              8.0.0-beta.26
@angular/material                 8.0.1
@angular/pwa                      0.800.4
@ngtools/webpack                  8.0.3
@schematics/angular               8.0.4
@schematics/update                0.800.3
rxjs                              6.5.2
typescript                        3.4.5
webpack                           4.30.0
**Anything else relevant?** There is an [existing issue](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/11123) related to this, but it has been closed by the OP, as he found a workaround by using a different folder. This does not seem to be the right solution for this, as it can cause wrong production bundles without showing an error or even a warning. Ideally, the CLI should be able to handle folders with space in the name correctly. If that's not possible, it should abort the build and show an error.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Assets not copied when path contains a space" (#15058)

Issues.Title: feat(@ngtools/webpack): show warning when a TS compilations contains ‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶unused files

When a tsconfig without `includes` or `files` all files under the `rootDir` will be included in the compilation. This results in redundant files to inserted as part of the ts compilation which in some cases might reduce the compilation drastically.

Related to: TOOL-949
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@ngtools/webpack): show warning when a TS compilations contains ‚Ä¶" (#15061)

Issues.Title: Support ng generate webWorker for libraries
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [x] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> I would like to use Web Workers in an Angular 8  library project.
In version  8.1.1 this seems to be supported for project type 'application' only:
```console
ng generate webWorker my-module/myWorker --project my-lib
Web Worker requires a project type of "application".
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Generating a Web Worker should work for project type 'library' as well.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Rewrite TypeScript worker code to JavaScript file.

Issues.Title: build: allow inspecting test nodejs process w/ bazel
Issues.Body:
Adds a new `debug` configuration for Bazel that can be used to
open the Chrome Devtools Debugger in order to debug a bazel
test that runs with NodeJS. This is similar to what `angular/angular`
provides.

*Note*: This does not make debugging for web test suites easier. For
web test suites we need to find a better solution. I have something in mind
where developers can run `bazel run` instead of `bazel test` to open the
karma test suite in non-capture mode (allowing easy debugging)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: allow inspecting test nodejs process w/ bazel" (#16525)

Issues.Title: Focus out is not reflected on select's arrow
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

The issue can be reproduced in [Material documentation](https://material.angular.io/components/select/overview) right away.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open options list and select an item
2. Focus out (click somewhere outside the select)
3. Look at the select's arrow. It still has the focus color.
 
#### Expected Behavior

The arrow should change the color after focusing out same as the underline or placeholder.


#### Actual Behavior

The arrow still has the focus color after focusing out.


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.1.0
- CDK/Material: 8.0.2
- Browser(s):  Safari/Mac, Safari/iPad
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): iOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Focus out is not reflected on select's arrow" (#16522)

Issues.Title: matNativeControl shows value that does not match model when options are changed, makes displayed option unselectable
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-native-select-option

Steps to reproduce:
1. Press Options 1 or Options 2, which changes the options displayed by both the native select and the mat-select.
2. Observe that the underlying control's value is null, but the native select shows the first option out of its options as the selected item.
3. Attempt to select the displayed value in the native dropdown. It appears selected,
4. Change focus away from the native control. The required validator will fire and the control will be invalid.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

No option should be displayed as no option was selected, as per the mat-select behaviour. 


#### Actual Behavior

The native control displays a value that does not match its model. Further, the option that is displayed can't actually be selected without selecting another option first.


#### Environment

- Angular: 7.2.15
- CDK/Material: 7.3.7
- Browser(s): Firefox 68 64 bit, Chrome 75.0.3770.100 64 bit
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10 1903 18362.207
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "matNativeControl shows value that does not match model when options are changed, makes displayed option unselectable" (#16519)

Issues.Title: mat-option keyboard events - unable to override
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-cdy9uu?file=app/select-overview-example.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. Bind a custom function to an `enter` or `space` keypress event on a `mat-option` element within `mat-select`.
2. Try pressing `enter` or `space` on one of the select options and observe that your function is not called.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior
The custom function should be called, just like `click` (which works).


#### Actual Behavior
The custom function bound to the keyboard event does not get called and seems to have no effect.


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.1.1
- CDK/Material: 8.0.2
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS

#### Notes
I see a similar situation [here](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/11654), but the solution seems pretty hacky with this direct manipulation of the DOM, and I'd like to see if there's a better way or something simple I am missing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "mat-option keyboard events - unable to override" (#16505)

Issues.Title: Icon documentation should demonstrate using <svg> and automatic theming
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

It's not clear from the icon documentation that `<mat-icon>` is a good use case for wrapping an `<svg>` icon for the sake of theming. Does not require registering the icon with the registry

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-rtrkyi?file=app/icon-svg-example.html
```
<mat-icon color="primary">

Issues.Title: feat(slide-toggle/checkbox): Custom true false value
Issues.Body:
**Use Case**
The default behaviour of slide-toggle/checkbox outputs Boolean true/false. The need for mapping the Boolean value to custom object needs to be handled outside the material component.

**Motivation**
Feature [ngTrueValue & ngFalseValue](https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/input/input[checkbox]) from AngularJS

**Change**
Added input attributes `trueValue` & `falseValue` for providing custom value.
The customised values will emit on ngModel/FormControl.
Emitted event will have additional field `value` holding this value.
Allows user to abstract logic that maps Boolean to custom value & vice versa.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(slide-toggle/checkbox): Custom true false value" (#16507)

Issues.Title: Add instructions to use mat-icon with alternative Material Icons themes
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

I recently noticed there are currently no instructions in the docs explaining how to use mat-icon with the alternative Material Icons themes (outlined, rounded, two-tone and sharp).

This may be because it is not officially supported, but I happened to find a way to make it work quite simply, so I thought it could be nice to reference this method in the docs.

I had to change the Material Icons font import url to https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons|Material+Icons+Outlined|Material+Icons+Two+Tone|Material+Icons+Round|Material+Icons+Sharp

and then use mat-icon like this: `<mat-icon fontSet="material-icons-round">home</mat-icon>`

This has been discussed in a feature request issue: #14853 

**Affected documentation page:** https://material.angular.io/components/icon
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add instructions to use mat-icon with alternative Material Icons themes" (#16508)

Issues.Title: Expansion panels in factoried content are open initially
Issues.Body:
Factoried components containing expansion panels will show the expansion panels as open when the component is inside another (like sidenav) that enters the DOM.  Non-factoried expansion panels do not have the same issue.  Likely related to https://github.com/angular/components/issues/11765

#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/sidenav-accordion-expansion

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the sidenav 
2. Should see the accordion is open during sidenav enter
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Sidenav should not be open during sidenav enter

#### Environment

- Angular: 8
- CDK/Material: 8
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): OSX High Sierra
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Expansion panels in factoried content are open initially" (#16503)
